summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary interview conducted by the DOJ Office of the Inspector General (OIG) with a Bureau of Prisons electronics technician at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York. The interview is part of an OIG investigation into the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein and the surrounding circumstances, specifically focusing on the failure of the MCC's camera recording system around the time of Epstein's death. The technician discusses his role, the chronic problems with the outdated camera system, the timeline of failures in July and August 2019, and his actions and communications with SIS staff and supervisors.

connections.description: The OIG agent is interviewing the BOP technician as part of the investigation into the camera failures surrounding Epstein's death.
The technician states that an SIS employee (likely or ) informed him on August 8th that the cameras were not recording and they couldn't pull video.
The technician consulted with the CSM about technical issues and obtained replacement hard drives from him to fix the camera recorders.
The technician's main point of contact at the camera system vendor for troubleshooting and instructions, especially regarding drive rebuilds.
The phone monitor, who had the key to the SIS room, told the technician he could not stay to work on the cameras after hours on August 9th.
The technician communicated with the Acting Warden about the gravity of the camera system failure on August 10th and the consequences of replacing drives.
The FBI agent interviewed the technician on March 12, 2020, and later took possession of all the DVR drives from the MCC on August 10th/11th, 2019.

events.title: DVR-2 System Failure
events.description: According to FBI/SigNet analysis cited in the interview, a system failure occurred on DVR-2, causing recordings to stop. The technician was unaware of this date until informed during the OIG interview.

events.title: Camera Recording Issue Discovered
events.description: SIS staff discovered they could not rewind or retrieve recorded video. The technician was notified (believes by SIS) and called SigNet for instructions. A SigNet service request was created.

events.title: Failed Attempt to Fix Cameras
events.description: The technician obtained replacement hard drives but could not gain access to the SIS/DVR room to install them because the keyholder (Phone Monitor) was leaving. He planned to return the next day.

events.title: Jeffrey Epstein Found Dead / Drive Replacement Attempt
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell. The technician gained access to the DVR room, began replacing the two failed hard drives, and warned that doing so would wipe any existing data. FBI agents arrived and took possession of all DVR drives.

events.title: New Camera System Installed
events.description: SigNet technicians arrived and installed the new camera recording system that had been on-site but not prioritized for months.

events.title: FBI Interview of Technician
events.description: The electronics technician was interviewed by the FBI, an AUSA, and a Task Force Officer regarding the camera system failures.

events.description: The DOJ Office of the Inspector General conducts this voluntary interview with the BOP electronics technician as part of its investigation into Epstein's death and the camera failures.

keyFacts: The MCC camera recording system was over 15-20 years old, analog, and plagued by chronic failures. The technician stated failures where recordings were lost happened multiple times before August 2019, and it was not treated as a high priority by management.

Technical analysis indicated a catastrophic disc failure in the DVR-2 raid array, and no recordings were available after July 29, 2019. The technician was unaware of this July 29th stop-date until the OIG interview.
On August 10, 2019, the technician began replacing two failed hard drives, a process he knew would wipe any existing data. FBI agents took possession of all DVR drives during this process.

A new camera recording system had been purchased and was on-site at the MCC for months prior to Epstein's death but was not installed due to a lack of priority and unclear management responsibility. It was installed the day after Epstein's death.

The technician asserts that prior to Epstein's death, there was no daily check or report to ensure cameras were recording, and that SIS and management failed to treat the recurring system failures with appropriate urgency, contrary to practices at his previous institutions.
